subject: Redfish: Query parameters: Only
commitMessage:
Redfish: Query parameters: Only

Add the query parameter "only" for redfish.
The specification is based on DSP0266_1.8.0.

When the query parameter carries only, it will check whether
the requested resource has only one member.
If it matches, The response will be replaced with the content
of the only member.

When there are query parameters, we will process the parameters
in res.end(). When the only parameter exists, we will get a new
url and call handle() again to get the resource.

Tested:
Validator passes.
Use the curl commond:
curl -i -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X GET
"https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems?only"

The response is same as the url
"https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system"

Signed-off-by: zhanghaicheng <zhanghch05@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I29f63e0b2231a9362b6d6ca65af3f820f8bc3c27

Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

This seems like a great start, but there's plenty to do still.

One thing you seem to have missed is the ServiceRoot changes required to publish that we now support this param.

Overall, I'd like to see us thinking about a generic filtering function that we can apply to resources as a whole.  LogServices does some of this today, but we need a more generic approach for not just only, but top, filter, and exapnd, so please be thinking about that as you go through this patchset.

I haven't reviewed all of the handler changes, only a subset, but they all seem to be similar.  I'll review all of them once we get the fixes we need in place.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> @Gunnar  @Ed Tanous
> Is it feasible to use this method? Change the "doGet code" of the collection‘s member to a separate function, which is called separately after judging the "param".

Based on what I know, this wont work, and would require separation of the AsyncResp from the handler anyway.  If we're going to do that, we might as well just make the core RAII compliant as well, as it means that all the other filtering and expand parameters become easier in the future.

> Will too much code be modified? Or cause more problems?

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/30295/ : SUCCESS

The "only" parameter specification requires:
When the incoming parameter contains more than "only",should return the HTTP 400 Bad Reques.
I want to add this to the next task code.
I have already received another query parameter (skip) story.
This doesn't work for anything other than only.  I'm all for making a generic query param grabber, but I'd like to see the existing query params moved to it first before it's used for new code.
This is incorrect.  Use find instead of operator[].

Same here, find is required over operator[]

Also, this needs to check for the existence of a single element, and return the appropriate return code if it's not there.

To my understanding, this isn't the correct way to implement the only param.  We should be returning the single resource, not a redirect to be queried later.  This largely defeats the purpose of the only param.
Please don't capture request by reference.  Do whatever things you need to do in the primary scope, then pass down the smaller variables to the lower scopes.
You're constructing an async resp here that then has multiple lifetimes.  http connection needs to own a weak_ptr to the asyncResp object.
This shouldn't be needed if you've done your reference counting correctly.
Ack
Don't reference count yourself, as the code is hard to get correct (this code is wrong in fact).  This is very likely your problem.  Use the shared_ptr.
Ack
As part of this, you need to remove ALL calls to res.end() in the codebase.  with asyncResp objects it's no longer required.

So I need to change all the "response & res" parameters in the code base to asyncresp objects? And remove all of them res.end . It's a big change. I think I should submit this part of the work to a new commit.  Is it？
Yes, that should be done in another commit.
Ack
Another thing you mentioned earlier is to use bmcweb:: asyncresp object instead of redfish:: asyncresp object. Is my submission based on your patch? Or do I submit a new one?

I don't understand the question.  To do this, part of the first task would require getting all of the core using the same AsyncResp object, which I have patchsets out to make them similar in behavior, which would likely help with your effort.

> part of the first task would require getting all of the core using the same AsyncResp object, which I have patchsets out to make them similar in behavior

Yes, this is it.
I browsed your dashboard and found that you seem to have not submitted the patch yet, so I have the above question.
The week starting tomorrow is our statutory holiday, so my work will be put on hold...

> > part of the first task would require getting all of the core using the same AsyncResp object, which I have patchsets out to make them similar in behavior
> 
> Yes, this is it.
> I browsed your dashboard and found that you seem to have not submitted the patch yet, so I have the above question.

I haven't written this patch, and it's a long ways down on my list to get done.  If you wanted to take it on because you needed it, feel free to push it, but it for sure needs done before this feature can work.

> The week starting tomorrow is our statutory holiday, so my work will be put on hold...

No problem at all.
Ack
this one can be removed, right?
Done
Can we do this one param at a time.  $skip is going to have consequences of doing it this way (as a post processing step) that I'd like to understand before we actually do that.

Do you mean that only one parameter is allowed at a time?
What I thought before was that multiple parameters may exist at the same time, and the combination of different parameters will have different effects. This is a very complicated job, and I haven't thought about how to deal with it. ONLY is a special parameter, because it is written in the manual that ONLY cannot appear with other parameters at the same time, so I chose to do this first.
If there is only one parameter at a time, the difficulty will be much lower.

No, i mean i'd like to see:

1. A commit to move the core to AsyncResp
2. A commit to add only
3. a commit to add skip

Splitting it up this way significantly helps with finding regressions.
Done
Please invert this check to save horizontal space.
Done
Please use the appropriate logging functions.
Done

Why are we clearing the response here?

I wonder if this kind of thing needs to be split up into pre-request checks and post-request checks, to avoid having to clear the container after we've filled it.
Done
Invert this check similar to the above.
Done
This duplicates the lookup of the "members" key with line 49.  Please deduplicate it.
Done
How about "Members contains more than one element, returning full collection."
Done
Need to check for existence of this before using it.
Done
This is not the call you want to do.  clear() should only be called from http connection.  You probably want to just clear the json body, which would be something like res.jsonBody.clear()
Done
I suspect we don't need a shared_ptr here.  A normal value type would be just fine.
Done
Keep in mind, you'll need to test that privileges work correctly in this case.
I don't quite understand, can you explain it in detail?

You're re-calling handle() which (I don't actually remember, but suspect) this has the potential to bypass the authorization system.

To prove that doesn't work, you'll need to find something you don't have access to, and attempt to $only to access it.  You should see 403 unauthorized, although we'll have to figure out if that actually works in practice.
Don't use std::endl.
Done

One thing I had imagined was that the AsyncResp class and the Response class could be combined, which would save this kind of diff everywhere.

Not necessarily something you need to tackle right away, but something to think about.
This also requires a lot of code changes, but this is not a very urgent matter. I will think about it.

Capturing this way is a bit dangerous on shutdown.  Ideally we'd use the App overload for the registration handler, but because the Node class still exists, there isn't a great way to solve this, as the node class relies on inheritence.

I'm not sure how to avoid doing

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/181

as part of this, but at some point this becomes boiling the ocean.  Lets get the AsyncResp stuff executed in one patch, then lets look at what it would take to get the ONLY parameters supported.

> I'm really not following.  I have no real problem with making a copy of the Request, because this is really a new request.
But here, the new request is a temporary variable.
When we call app.handle(), DBUS will be called in the code behind. When processing the return result of DBUS, the current function excuteQueryParamAll will return and the temporary variables will be released. Because req is not shared_ptr, and the transfer of req uses &, we will not be able to continue to use new requests in the callback function of DBUS.

> > I'm really not following.  I have no real problem with making a copy of the Request, because this is really a new request.
> But here, the new request is a temporary variable.

This has the potential for lifetime issues, because you're pointing at a request that might be destroyed during the lifetime while running this expand operation.  I suspect what needs to happen is something like what John is working on here: 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/44928

Which makes the request object a fully owning class, in that it owns the full lifetime of the data, and there's no shared ownership with the connection class.  This means that (similar to the original crow design) requests can be spun up without any connection class that originated the object.
